trans-unit.source: Build a Service that uses Table storage instead of a SQL Database | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Build a Service that uses Table storage instead of a SQL Database | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Learn how to use Azure Table storage with your .NET backend mobile service.
trans-unit.target: Learn how to use Azure Table storage with your .NET backend mobile service.

trans-unit.source: This topic shows you how to use a non-relational data store for your .NET backend mobile service.
trans-unit.target: This topic shows you how to use a non-relational data store for your .NET backend mobile service.

trans-unit.source: In this tutorial, you will modify the Azure Mobile Services quickstart project to use Azure Table storage instead of the default Azure SQL Database data store.
trans-unit.target: In this tutorial, you will modify the Azure Mobile Services quickstart project to use Azure Table storage instead of the default Azure SQL Database data store.

trans-unit.source: The tutorial requires completion of the [Get started with Mobile Services] or [Add Mobile Services to an existing app] tutorial.
trans-unit.target: The tutorial requires completion of the [Get started with Mobile Services] or [Add Mobile Services to an existing app] tutorial.

trans-unit.source: You will also need an Azure storage account.
trans-unit.target: You will also need an Azure storage account.

trans-unit.source: First, you need to configure your mobile service and .NET backend code project to connect to Azure storage.
trans-unit.target: First, you need to configure your mobile service and .NET backend code project to connect to Azure storage.

trans-unit.source: In Solution Explorer in Visual Studio, right-click the .NET backend project, and then select Manage NuGet Packages.
trans-unit.target: In Solution Explorer in Visual Studio, right-click the .NET backend project, and then select Manage NuGet Packages.

trans-unit.source: In the left pane, select the Online category, select Stabile Only, search for MobileServices, click Install on the Microsoft Azure Mobile Services .NET Backend Azure Storage Extension package, then accept the license agreements.
trans-unit.target: In the left pane, select the Online category, select Stabile Only, search for MobileServices, click Install on the Microsoft Azure Mobile Services .NET Backend Azure Storage Extension package, then accept the license agreements.

trans-unit.source: This adds support for Azure storage services to the .NET backend mobile service project.
trans-unit.target: This adds support for Azure storage services to the .NET backend mobile service project.

trans-unit.source: If you haven't yet created your storage account, see <linkText>How To Create a Storage Account</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: If you haven't yet created your storage account, see <linkText>How To Create a Storage Account</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: In the Management Portal, click Storage, click the storage account, then click Manage Keys.
trans-unit.target: In the Management Portal, click Storage, click the storage account, then click Manage Keys.

trans-unit.source: Make a note of the Storage Account Name and Access Key.
trans-unit.target: Make a note of the Storage Account Name and Access Key.

trans-unit.source: In your mobile service, click the Configure tab, scroll down to Connection strings and enter a new connection string with a Name of StorageConnectionString and a Value that is your storage account connection string in the following format.
trans-unit.target: In your mobile service, click the Configure tab, scroll down to Connection strings and enter a new connection string with a Name of StorageConnectionString and a Value that is your storage account connection string in the following format.

trans-unit.source: In the above string, replace the values of and with the values from the portal, then click Save.
trans-unit.target: In the above string, replace the values of and with the values from the portal, then click Save.

trans-unit.source: The storage account connection string is stored encrypted in app settings.
trans-unit.target: The storage account connection string is stored encrypted in app settings.

trans-unit.source: You can access this string in any table controller at runtime.
trans-unit.target: You can access this string in any table controller at runtime.

trans-unit.source: In Solution Explorer in Visual Studio, open the Web.config file for the mobile service project and add the following new connection string:
trans-unit.target: In Solution Explorer in Visual Studio, open the Web.config file for the mobile service project and add the following new connection string:

trans-unit.source: Replace the placeholder with the connection string from step 6.
trans-unit.target: Replace the placeholder with the connection string from step 6.

trans-unit.source: The mobile service uses this connection string when it runs on your local computer, which lets you test the code before you publish it.
trans-unit.target: The mobile service uses this connection string when it runs on your local computer, which lets you test the code before you publish it.

trans-unit.source: When running in Azure, the mobile service instead uses the connection string value set in the portal and ignores the connection string in the project.
trans-unit.target: When running in Azure, the mobile service instead uses the connection string value set in the portal and ignores the connection string in the project.

trans-unit.source: Because the TodoList quickstart project is designed to work with a SQL Database using Entity Framework, you need to make some updates in the project to work with Table storage.
trans-unit.target: Because the TodoList quickstart project is designed to work with a SQL Database using Entity Framework, you need to make some updates in the project to work with Table storage.

trans-unit.source: Modify the TodoItem data type to derive from StorageData instead of EntityData, as follows.
trans-unit.target: Modify the TodoItem data type to derive from StorageData instead of EntityData, as follows.

trans-unit.source: The StorageData type has an Id property that requires a compound key that is a string in the format partitionId,rowValue.
trans-unit.target: The StorageData type has an Id property that requires a compound key that is a string in the format partitionId,rowValue.

trans-unit.source: In TodoItemController, add the following using statement.
trans-unit.target: In TodoItemController, add the following using statement.

trans-unit.source: Replace the Initialize method of the TodoItemController with the following.
trans-unit.target: Replace the Initialize method of the TodoItemController with the following.

trans-unit.source: This create a new storage domain manager for the requested controller using the storage account connection string.
trans-unit.target: This create a new storage domain manager for the requested controller using the storage account connection string.

trans-unit.source: Replace the existing GetAllTodoItems method with the following code.
trans-unit.target: Replace the existing GetAllTodoItems method with the following code.

trans-unit.source: Unlike a SQL Database, this version doesn't return IQueryable<TEntity>, so the result can be bound to but not futher composed in a query.
trans-unit.target: Unlike a SQL Database, this version doesn't return IQueryable<TEntity>, so the result can be bound to but not futher composed in a query.

trans-unit.source: You need to make one change on the client side to make the quickstart app work with the .NET backend using Table storage.
trans-unit.target: You need to make one change on the client side to make the quickstart app work with the .NET backend using Table storage.

trans-unit.source: This is due to the compound key expected by the table storage provider.
trans-unit.target: This is due to the compound key expected by the table storage provider.

trans-unit.source: Open the client code file that contains the data access code and find the method where the insert operation performed.
trans-unit.target: Open the client code file that contains the data access code and find the method where the insert operation performed.

trans-unit.source: Update the TodoItem instance being added to explicitly set the Id field in the string format ,.
trans-unit.target: Update the TodoItem instance being added to explicitly set the Id field in the string format ,.

trans-unit.source: This is an example of how this ID might be set in a C# app, where the partition part is fixed and the row part is GUID-based.
trans-unit.target: This is an example of how this ID might be set in a C# app, where the partition part is fixed and the row part is GUID-based.

trans-unit.source: You are now ready to test the app.
trans-unit.target: You are now ready to test the app.

trans-unit.source: (Optional) Republish your mobile service .NET backend project.
trans-unit.target: (Optional) Republish your mobile service .NET backend project.

trans-unit.source: You can also test your mobile service locally before you publish the .NET backend project to Azure.
trans-unit.target: You can also test your mobile service locally before you publish the .NET backend project to Azure.

trans-unit.source: Whether you test locally or in Azure, the mobile service will be using the Azure Table storage.
trans-unit.target: Whether you test locally or in Azure, the mobile service will be using the Azure Table storage.

trans-unit.source: Run the quickstart client app connected to your mobile service.
trans-unit.target: Run the quickstart client app connected to your mobile service.

trans-unit.source: Note that you do not see items that you previously added using the quickstart tutorial.
trans-unit.target: Note that you do not see items that you previously added using the quickstart tutorial.

trans-unit.source: This is because the Table store is currently empty.
trans-unit.target: This is because the Table store is currently empty.

trans-unit.source: Add new items to generate database changes.
trans-unit.target: Add new items to generate database changes.

trans-unit.source: The app and mobile service should behave as before, except now your data is being stored in your non-relational store instead of in the SQL Database.
trans-unit.target: The app and mobile service should behave as before, except now your data is being stored in your non-relational store instead of in the SQL Database.

trans-unit.source: Now that you have seen how easy it is to use Table storage with .NET backend, consider exploring some other backend storage options:
trans-unit.target: Now that you have seen how easy it is to use Table storage with .NET backend, consider exploring some other backend storage options:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Use MongoDB as a data store with your Mobile Services.NET backend</linkText><title></title></br>Like the tutorial you just completed, this topic shows you how to use a non-relational data store for your mobile service. In this tutorial, you will modify the Mobile Services quickstart project to use MongoDB instead of SQL Database as the data store.
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Use MongoDB as a data store with your Mobile Services.NET backend</linkText><title></title></br>Like the tutorial you just completed, this topic shows you how to use a non-relational data store for your mobile service. In this tutorial, you will modify the Mobile Services quickstart project to use MongoDB instead of SQL Database as the data store.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Connect to an on-premises SQL Server using Hybrid Connections</linkText><title></title></br>Hybrid Connections lets your mobile service securely connect to your on-premises assets. In this way, you can make your on-premises data accessible to your mobile clients by using Azure. Supported assets include any resource that runs on a static TCP port, including Microsoft SQL Server, MySQL, HTTP Web APIs, and most custom web services.
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Connect to an on-premises SQL Server using Hybrid Connections</linkText><title></title></br>Hybrid Connections lets your mobile service securely connect to your on-premises assets. In this way, you can make your on-premises data accessible to your mobile clients by using Azure. Supported assets include any resource that runs on a static TCP port, including Microsoft SQL Server, MySQL, HTTP Web APIs, and most custom web services.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Upload images to Azure Storage using Mobile Services</linkText><title></title></br>Shows you how to extend the TodoList sample project to let you upload images from your app to Azure Blob storage.
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Upload images to Azure Storage using Mobile Services</linkText><title></title></br>Shows you how to extend the TodoList sample project to let you upload images from your app to Azure Blob storage.
